options.option_text: YES
NO

questions.question_text_1: FastText differs from traditional word embedding models like Word2Vec because it can handle out-of-vocabulary (OOV) words more effectively. Which of the following best explains how FastText achieves this capability?
question_texts: FastText differs from traditional word embedding models like Word2Vec because it can handle out-of-vocabulary (OOV) words more effectively. Which of the following best explains how FastText achieves this capability?

options.option_text: FastText predicts context words using an entire sentence rather than justnearby words.
FastText generates embeddings by averaging multiple pre-trained wordvectors.
FastText breaks words down into smaller subword units (character n-grams)and creates embeddings based on these subwords, allowing it to estimate embeddings for unseen words.
FastText uses neural networks with an additional layer dedicated to identifyingunknown words.

questions.question_text_2:
Consider the sentences: 
  In a transformer model, each word receives positional encoding. How will the positional encoding of "playful" differ across these sentences?
question_texts:
Consider the sentences: 
  In a transformer model, each word receives positional encoding. How will the positional encoding of "playful" differ across these sentences?

options.option_text: It will be identical in all three sentences.
It will vary in each sentence based on the position of "playful" within thatsentence.
It will vary only if "playful" has a different meaning.
It will be identical but scaled by the number of words in each sentence.

questions.question_text_1: In the encoder of a transformer model, what are the sources of the queries (Q), keys (K), and values (V)?
question_texts: In the encoder of a transformer model, what are the sources of the queries (Q), keys (K), and values (V)?

options.option_text: Q comes from the encoder output, K from the decoder input, and V from theoutput layer.
Q comes from the decoder output, while K and V come from the encoderinput.
Q comes from the positional encoding, K from the input sequence length, andV from the output embeddings.
Q, K, and V all come from the input embeddings representing the tokens inthe input sequence.

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following statements about statistical-based (SMT) and example-based (EBMT) machine translation techniques. Select all statements that are correct:
question_texts: Consider the following statements about statistical-based (SMT) and example-based (EBMT) machine translation techniques. Select all statements that are correct:

options.option_text: SMT uses probabilistic models to estimate the likelihood of translating onephrase to another.
EBMT relies on a database of example translations and reuses similarexamples to translate new sentences.
SMT requires extensive linguistic rules and manually defined grammar tocreate effective translations.
When EBMT encounters an unseen sentence, it decomposes the sentence intosmaller segments and reuses similar examples from its database to generate translations.

questions.question_text_1: Consider a scenario where you are fine-tuning a large language model using LoRA (Low-Rank Adaptation) and QLoRA (Quantized LoRA) techniques. Each technique has specific ways of reducing the model's memory and computational requirements. Select all statements that are correct about LoRA ans QLoRa.
question_texts: Consider a scenario where you are fine-tuning a large language model using LoRA (Low-Rank Adaptation) and QLoRA (Quantized LoRA) techniques. Each technique has specific ways of reducing the model's memory and computational requirements. Select all statements that are correct about LoRA ans QLoRa.

options.option_text: LoRA achieves computational efficiency by performing inference with only asubset of the model's original parameters, completely ignoring any layers that are not low-rank.
QLoRA enables the model to dynamically switch between full and low-rankmatrices during inference, improving accuracy while saving memory.
QLoRA applies quantization to the low-rank matrices introduced by LoRA,combining memory efficiency through quantization with a reduced number of trainable parameters from low-rank adaptation.
LoRA reduces the number of parameters by introducing low-rank matrices toapproximate the weight updates, which minimizes the number of parameters that need to be stored and trained.

questions.question_text_1:
You are analysing a collection of customer reviews using the Bag of Words (BoW) model. Here are three sample reviews: 
• Review 1: "This product is amazing, I absolutely love it!" 
• Review 2: "The product is terrible, I hate it." 
• Review 3: "Not the best, but it works okay."
questions.question_text_2:
You are analysing a collection of customer reviews using the Bag of Words (BoW) model. Here are three sample reviews: 
• Review 1: "This product is amazing, I absolutely love it!" 
• Review 2: "The product is terrible, I hate it." 
• Review 3: "Not the best, but it works okay." 
  Assume that each unique word from the vocabulary appears in at least one of the three reviews and each unique word from reviews are added in the vocabulary. A word that appears in a review contributes 1 non-zero entry to that review's BoW vector.
question_texts:
You are analysing a collection of customer reviews using the Bag of Words (BoW) model. Here are three sample reviews: 
• Review 1: "This product is amazing, I absolutely love it!" 
• Review 2: "The product is terrible, I hate it." 
• Review 3: "Not the best, but it works okay." 
You are analysing a collection of customer reviews using the Bag of Words (BoW) model. Here are three sample reviews: 
• Review 1: "This product is amazing, I absolutely love it!" 
• Review 2: "The product is terrible, I hate it." 
• Review 3: "Not the best, but it works okay." 
  Assume that each unique word from the vocabulary appears in at least one of the three reviews and each unique word from reviews are added in the vocabulary. A word that appears in a review contributes 1 non-zero entry to that review's BoW vector.

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations

#### 1. **Word Embeddings and FastText**
- **Concepts**: Word embeddings, FastText, subword units, character n-grams.
- **Principles**: FastText handles out-of-vocabulary (OOV) words by breaking them into subword units.
- **Equations**: None specific, but understanding of how embeddings are generated from subwords is crucial.

#### 2. **Positional Encoding in Transformers**
- **Concepts**: Positional encoding, transformers, attention mechanisms.
- **Principles**: Each word in a transformer model receives a positional encoding that varies based on its position in the sentence.
- **Equations**: None specific, but understanding the positional encoding formula is important.

#### 3. **Attention Masks in Decoders**
- **Concepts**: Attention masks, decoders, sequence length.
- **Principles**: Attention masks ensure that each token attends only to previous tokens.
- **Equations**: Ratio of masked positions to unmasked positions in an attention matrix.

#### 4. **Queries, Keys, and Values in Transformers**
- **Concepts**: Queries (Q), keys (K), values (V), input embeddings.
- **Principles**: Q, K, and V are derived from the input embeddings representing the tokens in the input sequence.
- **Equations**: None specific, but understanding the role of Q, K, and V in attention mechanisms is crucial.

#### 5. **TF-IDF (Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency)**
- **Concepts**: TF-IDF, term frequency, inverse document frequency.
- **Principles**: TF-IDF evaluates the importance of a term in a document relative to a collection of documents.
- **Equations**:
  \[
  \text{TF-IDF}(t, d) = \text{TF}(t, d) \times \text{IDF}(t)
  \]
  \[
  \text{TF}(t, d) = \frac{\text{Number of times term } t \text{ appears in document } d}{\text{Total number of terms in document } d}
  \]
  \[
  \text{IDF}(t) = \log \left( \frac{\text{Total number of documents}}{\text{Number of documents containing term } t} \right)
  \]

#### 6. **Machine Translation Techniques**
- **Concepts**: Statistical-based Machine Translation (SMT), Example-based Machine Translation (EBMT).
- **Principles**: SMT uses probabilistic models, EBMT relies on a database of example translations.
- **Equations**: None specific, but understanding the probabilistic models and example reuse mechanisms is important.

#### 7. **Fine-Tuning Large Language Models with LoRA and QLoRA**
- **Concepts**: LoRA (Low-Rank Adaptation), QLoRA (Quantized LoRA), low-rank matrices, quantization.
- **Principles**: LoRA reduces the number of parameters by introducing low-rank matrices, QLoRA applies quantization to these matrices.
- **Equations**: None specific, but understanding the reduction in parameters and memory efficiency is crucial.

#### 8. **Bag of Words (BoW) Model**
- **Concepts**: Bag of Words, word frequencies, vocabulary.
- **Principles**: BoW model represents text as a bag of its words, disregarding grammar and word order but keeping multiplicity.
- **Equations**: None specific, but understanding how to count non-zero entries in BoW vectors is important.

#### 9. **Positional Encoding Vectors**
- **Concepts**: Positional encoding, embedding dimension, unique elements.
- **Principles**: Each word is represented by a positional encoding vector with a specific embedding dimension.
- **Equations**: None specific, but understanding how to identify unique elements in vectors is important.

#### 10. **Byte Pair Encoding (BPE) Algorithm**
- **Concepts**: Byte Pair Encoding, token merging, unique tokens.
- **Principles**: BPE merges the most frequent pairs of consecutive bytes to reduce the number of unique tokens.
- **Equations**: None specific, but understanding the merging process and its impact on the number of unique tokens is crucial.

#### 11. **Memory Reduction in LoRA and QLoRA**
- **Concepts**: Memory reduction, quantization, low-rank matrices.
- **Principles**: LoRA and QLoRA reduce memory requirements by using low-rank matrices and quantization.
- **Equations**:
  \[
  \text{Percentage Reduction} = \left(1 - \frac{\text{Memory for Quantized Low-Rank Matrix}}{\text{Memory for Unquantized Full-Rank Matrix}}\right) \times 100
  \]

#### 12. **Bradley-Terry Model for Pairwise Preference Probabilities**
- **Concepts**: Bradley-Terry model, reward model, pairwise preference probabilities.
- **Principles**: The Bradley-Terry model computes the probability that one item is preferred over another.
- **Equations**:
  \[
  P(y_i \text{ is preferred over } y_j) = \frac{e^{R(y_i)}}{e^{R(y_i)} + e^{R(y_j)}}
  \]

#### 13. **Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) for Parameter Reduction**
- **Concepts**: Low-rank adaptation, parameter reduction, rank of matrices.
- **Principles**: LoRA reduces the number of parameters by introducing low-rank matrices.
- **Equations**: None specific, but understanding how to calculate the rank required to reduce parameters is important.

#### 14. **Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) for Language Modeling**
- **Concepts**: RNNs, embedding matrices, recurrent connections, feed-forward connections, unembedding matrices.
- **Principles**: RNNs use embedding matrices to convert input tokens into embedding vectors and unembedding matrices to convert hidden layer vectors to logits.
- **Equations**:
  \[
  h_t = \sigma(U h_{t-1} + W x_t)
  \]
  where \( h_t \) is the hidden layer output at time step \( t \), \( x_t \) is the input token at time step \( t \), \( U \) and \( W \) are weight matrices, and \( \sigma \) is the activation function.

#### 15. **Cross-Entropy Loss with Softmax**
- **Concepts**: Cross-entropy loss, softmax, word probabilities.
- **Principles**: Cross-entropy loss with softmax is used to train RNNs for language modeling tasks.
- **Equations**:
  \[
  \text{Loss} = -\log(p_{\text{true word}})
  \]
  where \( p_{\text{true word}} \) is the probability of the true word.

### Knowledge Graph 

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Natural Language Processing] --> B[Word Embeddings];
    A --> C[Transformers];
    A --> D[Machine Translation];
    A --> E[Fine-Tuning Models];
    A --> F[Bag of Words];
    A --> G[Byte Pair Encoding];
    A --> H[Recurrent Neural Networks];

    B --> B1[FastText];
    B --> B2[Subword Units];

    C --> C1[Positional Encoding];
    C --> C2[Attention Masks];
    C --> C3[Queries, Keys, Values];

    D --> D1[Statistical-based Machine Translation];
    D --> D2[Example-based Machine Translation];

    E --> E1[LoRA];
    E --> E2[QLoRA];

    F --> F1[Word Frequencies];
    F --> F2[Vocabulary];

    G --> G1[Token Merging];
    G --> G2[Unique Tokens];

    H --> H1[Embedding Matrices];
    H --> H2[Recurrent Connections];
    H --> H3[Feed-forward Connections];
    H --> H4[Unembedding Matrices];
    H --> H5[Cross-Entropy Loss];
```

```mermaid
graph TD;
    I[Core Concepts] --> J[TF-IDF];
    I --> K[Bradley-Terry Model];
    I --> L[Low-Rank Adaptation];

    J --> J1[Term Frequency];
    J --> J2[Inverse Document Frequency];

    K --> K1[Pairwise Preference Probabilities];

    L --> L1[Parameter Reduction];
    L --> L2[Quantization];
```

This summary and knowledge graph should help you focus on the essential topics and concepts for your exam.
